A WORNOCT TRADITION
HI BETA KAPPA holds as initiation ceremony tomorrow night.
May the fourth_ Undergraduate examinations were over on the
fifth of February; three months have elapsed between these dates. During this entire time the men who will be initiated tomorrow night
have been deprived of the benefits and . pleasures accruing from meinbership in this revered organization. Furthermore, they will not receive their insignia of membership, the much-coveted key, for about
two weeks. They leave Hopkins cat June eleventh, thus 'being accorded the privilege of wearing their key on the campus foi about
three weeks..
There is no wait' r&i.witt•WhY• Phi Beta Kappa should not hold
its initiation before the end of February. The practice of waiting
until after Easter to elect members arose many years ago -when the
college year was divided into three semesters. At that time it was
necessary to wait until May to elect since all .the data could not be
'obtained until that time. When the college abandoned the tri-pari
tite -Year in favor of the present system,'Phi Bet:kr-K-4N Made no
effort to change their election date., •
The constitution of the Hopkins chapter contains .a provision,
which prohibits the annual meeting being held until after Easter..
The only reason that remains for not -changing this clause is the no,
toricius laissez-faire policy of the faculty.
No excuse for this dilatory procedure can be offered on the
months to compile
several
grounds that it takes the Registrar's office
the necessary averages, since at the end of the college year, the office
has all the statistics for every class ready within two weeks after the
final examinations.
Traditions, of course, are to be respected, if only because of
the fact that they are procedures usually instituted for good 'reasons
and these good reasons command approbation for a number of
years. But when the excti.se for a tradition becomes non-existent.
the tradition may better be called an abuse.

AN OPPORTUNITY

•

an'tOR three years we have been hearing the complaint that Hop'
kins offers no opportunity for ':college life.- A humdrum
existence; just the same damn thing over and over; dead as a door'
nail; all these expressions and many more have been used to describe.
undergraduate life at Homewood.
The Junior Class offers an opportunity tomorrow night to
-flaming youth.- The Hill Party will be the sort of affair these
pretended blase individuals are desiring. Something new; something different; something unexpected is being offered. Let us see if
the campus will take advantage of its .opportunity.
The Class of '30 is going to a great deal of trouble and expense
to make tomorrow'S affair the most elaborate of its kind ever staged
by any Hopkins organization. The committee is not asking the
attendance of the undergraduate body merely as a means of supporting the venture; they are urging the students to attend because they
are sure an enjoyable time will be had by all.

To-day mining is a business, with electricity
replacing wasteful brawn in mine and mill.
The deep mine, with electric lights, hoists, and
locomotives: the surface mine with huge electric
shovels scooping up tons of ore in a single bite:
the concentrating mill with its batieries of electrically driven machinei;the steel mill with its con-stant :electric heat—here are but al few of electricity's contributions'to the mineral 'industries.

A WORNOCT TRADITION
HI BETA KAPPA holds as initiation ceremony tomorrow night.
May the fourth_ Undergraduate examinations were over on the
fifth of February; three months have elapsed between these dates. During this entire time the men who will be initiated tomorrow night
have been deprived of the benefits and . pleasures accruing from meinbership in this revered organization. Furthermore, they will not receive their insignia of membership, the much-coveted key, for about
two weeks. They leave Hopkins cat June eleventh, thus 'being accorded the privilege of wearing their key on the campus foi about
three weeks..
There is no wait' r&i.witt•WhY• Phi Beta Kappa should not hold
its initiation before the end of February. The practice of waiting
until after Easter to elect members arose many years ago -when the
college year was divided into three semesters. At that time it was
necessary to wait until May to elect since all .the data could not be
'obtained until that time. When the college abandoned the tri-pari
tite -Year in favor of the present system,'Phi Bet:kr-K-4N Made no
effort to change their election date., •
The constitution of the Hopkins chapter contains .a provision,
which prohibits the annual meeting being held until after Easter..
The only reason that remains for not -changing this clause is the no,
toricius laissez-faire policy of the faculty.
No excuse for this dilatory procedure can be offered on the
months to compile
several
grounds that it takes the Registrar's office
the necessary averages, since at the end of the college year, the office
has all the statistics for every class ready within two weeks after the
final examinations.
Traditions, of course, are to be respected, if only because of
the fact that they are procedures usually instituted for good 'reasons
and these good reasons command approbation for a number of
years. But when the excti.se for a tradition becomes non-existent.
the tradition may better be called an abuse.

•

an'tOR three years we have been hearing the complaint that Hop'
kins offers no opportunity for ':college life.- A humdrum
existence; just the same damn thing over and over; dead as a door'
nail; all these expressions and many more have been used to describe.
undergraduate life at Homewood.
The Junior Class offers an opportunity tomorrow night to
-flaming youth.- The Hill Party will be the sort of affair these
pretended blase individuals are desiring. Something new; something different; something unexpected is being offered. Let us see if
the campus will take advantage of its .opportunity.
The Class of '30 is going to a great deal of trouble and expense
to make tomorrow'S affair the most elaborate of its kind ever staged
by any Hopkins organization. The committee is not asking the
attendance of the undergraduate body merely as a means of supporting the venture; they are urging the students to attend because they
are sure an enjoyable time will be had by all.
